PLH - Content - Time - CheckIn - One on.message_text: It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. Can you think of a time each day that you can make 5 minutes or a bit more? You can even make household chores into a game to do together. Even 5 minutes can make a big difference!
It can make you feel bad if your children do not want to spend One-on-One Time with you. Think to yourself: When are they more open to you? Maybe in the morning or right before bedtime.
condition: My child did not want to spend time with me

PLH - Content - Time - CheckIn - One on.message_text: @fields.child_nickname

You can also just sit next to @fields.child_nickname while they are doing something they enjoy (like watching a T.V. show) and show them that you are interested in what they like. If you take their lead they will see that you care.

You can also just sit next to your child while they are doing something they enjoy (like watching a T.V. show) and show them that you are interested in what they like. If you take their lead they will see that you care.
Children often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Sometimes you might want to give them some other fun options to do instead (Type: "Help" if you want a suggestion).
condition: All my child wanted to do is watch T.V. or play with a gadget

PLH - Content - Time - CheckIn - One on.message_text: @fields.child_nickname

You can also find something educational to do together with @fields.child_nickname on the gadget. Or maybe ask @fields.child_nickname to show you what is their favourite thing to do on the gadget. Just be patient. Soon they may open up to other activities, too!

You can also find something educational to do together with your child on the gadget. Or maybe ask your child to show you what is their favourite thing to do on the gadget. Just be patient. Soon they may open up to other activities, too!

Sometimes our children will suggest activities that are violent or unsafe. Explain why they can't, and try suggesting alternative activities that would be more appropriate. Type "Help" if you want a suggestion.
condition: My child wanted to do things I felt uncomfortable about

PLH - Content - Time - CheckIn - One on.message_text: @fields.child_nickname
condition: My child wanted to do activities that I could not do

If @fields.child_nickname wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch @fields.child_nickname. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!

If @fields.child_nickname wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch your child. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!
@fields.child_nickname

If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch @fields.child_nickname. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!

If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch your child. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!

Competitive games can be challenging for children (and adults!) if they have difficulty losing. You may want to suggest other activities that you can play together instead of against each other (Type "Help" if you want a suggestion").

The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for @fields.child_nickname. Try giving @fields.child_nickname a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."

The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for @fields.child_nickname. Try giving your child a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."
@fields.child_nickname

The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for your child. Try giving @fields.child_nickname a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."

The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for your child. Try giving your child a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."
@fields.child_nickname

If @fields.child_nickname is too young to understand how long a minute is, then you can set a number of time to repeat the activity: "5 more tries and then it will be time for wash our hands before dinner…"
If your child is too young to understand how long a minute is, then you can set a number of time to repeat the activity: "5 more tries and then it will be time for wash our hands before dinner…"
@fields.child_nickname

Only give the transition warning once. When One-on-One Time is over, thank @fields.child_nickname for spending time with you. Then enthusiastically redirect @fields.child_nickname to the next activity like washing hands before dinner.

Only give the transition warning once. When One-on-One Time is over, thank your child for spending time with you. Then enthusiastically redirect your child to the next activity like washing hands before dinner.
@fields.child_nickname
condition: My child wanted to do too many things at once

PLH - Content - Time - CheckIn - One on.message_text: If @fields.child_nickname is very young, it is normal for them to have a short attention span and want to do many things during One-on-One Time. Just accept @fields.child_nickname and follow their lead moving from one activity to the next.

If your child is very young, it is normal for them to have a short attention span and want to do many things during One-on-One Time. Just accept your child and follow their lead moving from one activity to the next.

It can be difficult to spend One-on-One Time with each one child when you have more than one child. If possible, you can ask another adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend One-on-One Time with one child.
condition: All my children wanted One-on-One Time at the same time

PLH - Content - Time - CheckIn - One on.message_text: You can also think of times when it would be easier to spend One-on-One Time each child, like later in the evening with an older child after the others have gone to sleep.

You can also spend One-on-One Time with all of your children at once! 
Type "Help" for activities that you can do as a whole family

Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your baby!

The first 1000 days of life are a window of opportunity for your baby. It is when their brain develops faster than any other time in their life. When you spend time with your baby, you build a healthy attachment between you both that will make them feel secure and loved.
@fields.gender_personalisation

It is normal for men of the family to struggle to think of what to do with their babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.

It is normal for mothers to struggle to think of what to do with their babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.

It is normal to struggle to think of what to do with our babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.

Here are 7 easy tips to make One-on-One Time with your baby a success:

1. Do it every day
2. Be close to your baby
3. Let your baby take the lead
4. Observe and listen to your child
5. Play with your baby
6. Talk to your baby
7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime! 

To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "7". You can also type "N" to move on.
@fields.child_nickname

1. Do it every day!
Try to spend time playing with @fields.child_nickname every day for at least 20 minutes where you are giving them your full attention. Choose a time when you are unlikely to be interrupted. Switch off the television and put away phones.

1. Do it every day!
Try to spend time playing with your baby every day for at least 20 minutes where you are giving them your full attention. Choose a time when you are unlikely to be interrupted. Switch off the television and put away phones.

2. Be close to your child. 
Skin-to-skin contact is especially important for new-borns and infants. For older toddlers, make sure you are at the same level as they are.

3. Let your baby take the lead
Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Remember that the world is brand new to your child!
@fields.child_nickname

Give just enough help to let it be the child’s achievement. It is okay to play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative. If @fields.child_nickname gets frustrated, you can reassure @fields.child_nickname by gently stroking their back.

Give just enough help to let it be the child’s achievement. It is okay to play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative. If your child gets frustrated, you can reassure your child by gently stroking their back.
@fields.child_nickname

4. Observe your child. 
See what facial expressions @fields.child_nickname is making. Notice what @fields.child_nickname is interested in or looking at.

4. Observe your child. 
See what facial expressions your child is making. Notice what your child is interested in or looking at.
@fields.child_nickname
Listen to the sounds or words @fields.child_nickname is making. You can even make the same sounds by copying @fields.child_nickname!
Listen to the sounds or words your child is making. You can even make the same sounds by copying your child!
@fields.child_nickname

5. Play with your baby
Babies learn through play! Help your child explore the world through the five senses. Let @fields.child_nickname use all of their senses when exploring the world. Sometimes when you read to @fields.child_nickname, @fields.child_nickname will want to put the book in their mouth. That is okay!

5. Play with your baby
Babies learn through play! Help your child explore the world through the five senses. Let your child use all of their senses when exploring the world. Sometimes when you read to your child, your child will want to put the book in their mouth. That is okay!
@fields.child_nickname

It is okay for @fields.child_nickname to want to do many different things. @fields.child_nickname’s attention may wander to many different things during One-on-One Time. Anything that is happening can grab their attention: the sound of a car, the feeling of a breeze from a fan, feelings in the body. Just keep your attention on @fields.child_nickname.

It is okay for your child to want to do many different things. Your child’s attention may wander to many different things during One-on-One Time. Anything that is happening can grab their attention: the sound of a car, the feeling of a breeze from a fan, feelings in the body. Just keep your attention on your child.
@fields.child_nickname

6. Talk to your baby
Start talking to @fields.child_nickname from the moment they are born (even before when they are in the womb). Did you know @fields.child_nickname can even recognise their name at a very early age? Try saying your baby's name and notice how they respond!

6. Talk to your baby
Start talking to your baby from the moment they are born (even before when they are in the womb). Did you know your baby can even recognise their name at a very early age? Try saying your baby's name and notice how they respond!
@fields.child_nickname

Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening. Speak with enthusiasm when describing what @fields.child_nickname is doing.

Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening. Speak with enthusiasm when describing what your child is doing.
@fields.child_nickname

7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime! 
Look for ways you can connect with @fields.child_nickname playfully during feeding, bathing, and dressing. You can even make bedtime a fun and nurturing experience for you and @fields.child_nickname in a calm way.

7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime! 
Look for ways you can connect with your baby playfully during feeding, bathing, and dressing. You can even make bedtime a fun and nurturing experience for you and your baby in a calm way.

Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your baby:

2. Be close to your baby
3. Let your baby take the lead
4. Observe and listen to your child
5. Play with your baby
6. Talk to your baby
7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime! 

You can also type "N" to move on.
@(fields.one_time_baby_list_of_tips&results.list_of_tips&",")

Today's tip is about spending One-on-One Time with Our Children.
Here is a comic on spending one-on-one time with your child.

Child: “I’m bored! There is nothing to do.”

(1)

Parent: “Let’s do something together! How about we make some drawings and put them on the gate with messages for people to see?”

Children: “Okay!”

(2)

Parent: “You make the pictures and I’ll write the messages”

Child: “Sure!”

(3)

Parent: "Remember to wash hands! We love our neighbours!” 

(4)

Here are 6 tips to make One-on-One Time with your child a success:

1. Spend at least five minutes with each child
2. Give your child your full attention
3. Let your child choose the activity
4. Follow your child's lead
5. Use words to describe what your child is doing
6. Have fun!

To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.

1. Spend at least five minutes with each child
Even 5 minutes a day of quality time makes a big difference. If you have more than one child, try to find time for each individual child. It can be at the same time each day so your children look forward to it.
@fields.child_nickname

2. Give your child your full attention
Make sure you will not be interrupted. Finish all your chores, switch off the TV and put your phone on silent. It will show @fields.child_nickname, they are important.

2. Give your child your full attention
Make sure you will not be interrupted. Finish all your chores, switch off the TV and put your phone on silent. It will show your child, they are important.
@fields.child_nickname

3. Let your child choose the activity
Ask @fields.child_nickname what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?"

3. Let your child choose the activity
Ask your child what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?"
Choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t okay, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.
@fields.child_nickname
If @fields.child_nickname cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.
If your child cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.

4. Follow your child's lead
Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative.
@fields.child_nickname

5. Use words to describe what your child is doing
Listening to @fields.child_nickname is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what @fields.child_nickname is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!

5. Use words to describe what your child is doing
Listening to your child is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what your child is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!
@fields.child_nickname

6. Have fun!
One-on-One Time with your child can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after playing with @fields.child_nickname.

6. Have fun!
One-on-One Time with your child can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after playing with your child.

Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your child:

1. Spend at least five minutes with each child
2. Give your child your full attention
3. Let your child choose the activity
4. Follow your child's lead
5. Use words to describe what your child is doing
6. Have fun!

You can also type "N" to move on.

PLH - Content - Time - One on one time c.save_name: one time child list of tips

PLH - Content - Time - One on one time c.message_text: Here is a comic about spending one-on-one time with your child! Try to follow your child's lead when spending time with them. It will help build self-confidence.

Parent: "I see you are playing quietly with the lego with concentration, Alex."

(1)

Parent: "Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall with those legos."

Child: "It is for cows."

(2)

Parent: "It will keep the cow safe!"

Child: "Now you can help me build a house for our family to sleep in!"

(3)

Parent: "This house is going to keep our family warm and dry. You are such a good builder, Alex!"

(4)

PLH - Content - Time - One on one time t.message_text: One-on-one time
PLH - Internal - Update incomplete toolkits
Today's tip is about spending One-on-One Time with Our Children.
Here is a comic on spending one-on-time with your teen.

Child: “I’m bored! There is nothing to do.”

(1)

Parent: “Let’s do something together! How about we make some drawings and put them on the gate with messages for people to see?”

Children: “Okay!”

(2)

Parent: “You make the pictures and I’ll write the messages”

Child: “Sure!”

(3)

Parent: "Remember to wash hands! We love our neighbours!” 

(4)

One-on-one time
PLH - Internal - Update incomplete toolkits
@fields.from_theme
Invest in One-on-One Time! The more time you spend with your children, the more likely they will listen to you and behave well at other times. It really works!
@parent.results.fromwelcome
@fields.type_of_media
@fields.child_nickname

@fields.child_nickname

Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your teen!
@fields.gender_personalisation

Fathers can have difficult relationships with their teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.

Mothers can have difficult relationships with their teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.

When we have difficult relationships with our teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.

One-on-One Time with your teen helps build a positive and trusting relationship. When you really notice them and listen to what they are saying and what they like, you make them feel valued and appreciated.
Would you like to learn more about this tip?

Here are 6 tips on how to make One-on-One Time a positive experience for you and your teen:

1. Do it every day
2. Let your teen choose the activity
3. Follow your teen's lead
4. Give your teen your full attention
5. Show your teen you are really listening
6. Have fun!

To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.
@fields.child_nickname

1. Do it every day
Set aside a specific time to spend One-on-One Time with @fields.child_nickname each day. Choose a time when you and @fields.child_nickname will not be interrupted and when @fields.child_nickname does not have something else that they want to do, like watching TV or playing with phones.

1. Do it every day
Set aside a specific time to spend One-on-One Time with your teen each day. Choose a time when you and your teen will not be interrupted and when your teen does not have something else that they want to do, like watching TV or playing with phones.
@fields.child_nickname

2. Let your teen choose the activity
Tell @fields.child_nickname that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. @fields.child_nickname might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy having this dedicated time with you!

2. Let your teen choose the activity
Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. Your teen might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy having this dedicated time with you!
@fields.child_nickname

Try to do something different than watching TV or playing with a tablet/phone. However, you may need to at first join @fields.child_nickname and watch their favourite TV programme with them. They may feel comfortable doing other activities with time.

Try to do something different than watching TV or playing with a tablet/phone. However, you may need to at first join your teen and watch their favourite TV programme with them. They may feel comfortable doing other activities with time.
@fields.child_nickname

3. Follow your teen's lead
Try to follow @fields.child_nickname's lead during One-on-One Time. Accept their suggestions. Remember this is @fields.child_nickname's activity. Your job is to show an interest and say something nice.

3. Follow your teen's lead
Try to follow your teen's lead during One-on-One Time. Accept their suggestions. Remember this is your teen's activity. Your job is to show an interest and say something nice.
@fields.child_nickname

4. Give your teen all of your attention. 
Switch off the television and put away phones. Make sure you can give all of your attention to @fields.child_nickname.

4. Give your teen all of your attention. 
Switch off the television and put away phones. Make sure you can give all of your attention to your teen.
@fields.child_nickname
Look at @fields.child_nickname. Nodding or “I see” shows @fields.child_nickname you are really paying attention. Accept what they are saying without judging them.
Look at your teen. Nodding or “I see” shows your teen you are really paying attention. Accept what they are saying without judging them.
@fields.child_nickname

5. Show your teen you are really listening

You can even try rephrasing back what @fields.child_nickname says when they speak to you. For example, when @fields.child_nickname says, “This math problem is really hard,” you can say, “Yeah, I see that you are finding it difficult.” It shows you are really listening to them and will make them feel supported.

5. Show your teen you are really listening

You can even try rephrasing back what your teen says when they speak to you. For example, when your teen says, “This math problem is really hard,” you can say, “Yeah, I see that you are finding it difficult.” It shows you are really listening to them and will make them feel supported.
@fields.child_nickname

6. Have fun!
One-on-One Time with your teen can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after spending time with @fields.child_nickname.

6. Have fun!
One-on-One Time with your teen can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after spending time with your teen.

Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your teen:

1. Do it every day
2. Let your teen choose the activity
3. Follow your teen's lead
4. Give your teen your full attention
5. Show your teen you are really listening
6. Have fun!

You can also type "N" to move on.

PLH - Content - Time - One on one time t.save_name: one time teen list of tips

PLH - Content - Time - One on one time t.message_text: @fields.child_nickname
Here is a comic that shows how you can give @fields.child_nickname love and support when they share difficult emotions with you.

Parent: “How are you doing, Andy?”

Teen (looking sad): “I wish I could hang out with my friends.”

(1)

Parent (thinking): "Hmmm…that can wait…"

(2)

Parent (looks back to teen): “I understand it is hard to be separate from your friends. Especially since I am sure they are missing you, too. Let’s think of some ways that you could reach out to them.”

(3)

Teen: "Maybe I can make a TikTok video to share with them. But I am not sure how…can you help me?”

Parent: “I would be happy to help and would like to know more about TikTok, too!”

(4)
Here is a comic that shows how you can give your teen love and support when they share difficult emotions with you.

Parent: “How are you doing, Andy?”

Teen (looking sad): “I wish I could hang out with my friends.”

(1)

Parent (thinking): "Hmmm…that can wait…"

(2)

Parent (looks back to teen): “I understand it is hard to be separate from your friends. Especially since I am sure they are missing you, too. Let’s think of some ways that you could reach out to them.”

(3)

Teen: "Maybe I can make a TikTok video to share with them. But I am not sure how…can you help me?”

Parent: “I would be happy to help and would like to know more about TikTok, too!”

(4)
